Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story:
Sunday morning sunlight streamed through my apartment window as I sat hunched over my laptop, blueprints and code scattered around me. The project team had just started exploring ideas for a new system, and my manager expected me to brainstorm technical solutions before our Monday meeting. I knew I could propose alternatives later, but the pressure to impress my colleagues and show initiative gnawed at me. 

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder: church service in an hour. I’d missed last week, and the pastor had gently reminded me how important it was to worship together and support our community. I felt a pang of guilt—my faith taught me to honor God and be present for others, not just when it was convenient. 

My mind raced, torn between the urge to keep working and the call to join my church family. I stared at the clock, heart pounding, wrestling with the weight of both expectations pressing in from either side.
